It is obvious when taking the picture where the autofocus is centered and it usually is looking at what I am looking at.This camera is FANTASTIC!  Totally worth the price.  The picture quality is BEAUTIFUL.  The flash creates such soft and beautiful images ( as compared to my previous model).  I've not even had to deal with a more professional flash yet.The lens is heavy, but I used to interchange lenses (18-55 and 75-300).  I often had the wrong lens with me and was too busy to change to the one I really wanted.  Typically I carried the 75-300 most of the time anyway.  That lens used to unwind and hang down.  I have not had this problem with this lens.  There is a lock feature to prevent it, but the lens seems to be better designed to prevent this so far.  This lens is pretty much all inclusive for every day photography.I did get a hood to protect the lens (Canon EW-73B Lens Hood For 17-85mm), and I am glad.  I carry this camera everywhere and the hood (on in reverse) is cheep and keeps me from knocking the lens....and as someone said in the hood review...makes you look like you know what you are doing.I got the Transcend 64GB Class 10 SDXC Flash Memory Card.  It seems to work well and can hold tons of imaging.  I didn't want to keep downloading pics to keep my card available for more images.  In fact, I plan to use it a backup storage and get a new card when it is full.The video quality is fine for regular applications.  I have a canon videocamera as well, so I don't spend a lot of time with this video feature.  But the little clips I have taken of my infant are better than what I get on my phone so I'm happy.Love love love this camera.  Buy it!

Reviews.Title: Ah, finally back in a Canon EOS
Reviews.Author: S. Mc
Reviews.Content: I had long used Canon DSLRs, but over a year ago, I decided to switch to a mirrorless (Sony NEX-5n) camera as a way to go lighter and supposedly get just as good results.  In reality, that's only sometimes the case.  I found myself struggling with really limited lens selection (and none of them were great), terrible solutions for external flashes (holy hell Sony), and decent pictures when those two things weren't affecting it.After the last round of Christmas program photos, and our Christmas family photo, I had enough and decided to come back to a full DSLR.  I've read a lot of reviews, compared specs, etc.  Seems like all the DSLRs at this level/price have their own pro/cons, but most are good cameras.  Some of the things that drew me back to Canon were the following:Historically good APS-C sensor, now with DIGIC 5 processingDecent kit lens that will keep you going until you save for some L glass. (Of course, you should always have a nifty 50 lens as well).Nice touchscreen interface (I didn't think I'd care, but starting to like it)Nice HD video recordingSilent focusing in video with new STM lenses (No more hearing focusing noises in the audio)Access to large lens selectionAccess to large flash selectionWhile I haven't had this new body very long, i have been using it a lot, and am really pleased with the decision to stay with Canon here.  Photos look great, and I find it easier to get the result I am after.  My wife instantly noticed the quality change of some of the kid photos, etc.  Tethered shooting works great with the included Canon software.  The 18MP photos are plenty of resolution to produce large prints. High ISO shooting up to 3200 looks great, noise becomes more noticeable when you crank past that point.The focusing system seems to work much better than my old 20D. It's an all around good package.The only thing I wish it had was wifi integration for remote control from a smartphone/tablet/computer.  Other models are beginning to integrate such features, I think Canon should have gone this way.Additionally, from what i've read, there doesn't seem to be much here over the T4i. If you have that and like it, I can't imagine why you'd be interested in this one.  For the rest of us with older models, it's a great upgrade.

Reviews.Title: High Quality "Prosumer grade" camera
Reviews.Author: good_equipment_bad_photographer "good_equipme...
Reviews.Content: Canon is simply the best.  The pictures, especially with a good lens are sharp, contrasty and even better color than my 40D especially with the 17-55 F2.8 lens!  With the new Digic 5 processor, flesh tones are absolutely gorgeous, perfect for portrait photography, and much more. Highly recommended

Reviews.Title: Long time Canon user
Reviews.Author: Bisko
Reviews.Content: I will leave all the Techie issues to more knowledgeable persons.  That said, this camera with the 18-135 mm lens, is all that it should be for a simple but very good picture-taking machine.  Fast shutter speed, low light capability, decent built-in flash, movie mode.  It's all that.  With a 32gb and a 64gb card, one for photos and one for videos, it's all I will probably ever need or want.  'course I started with an EOS 650 back in the day, and this is just the icing.  After a couple of smaller hand-held cameras, this is as good as it gets.  Used it last month, in Puerto Vallarta and shot almost 500 photos and about an hour of videos, every shot was fine.  Pics can be blown up dramatically without too much pixellation.  I'm sure there are better cameras out there, but this is the last camera I will ever buy.  Hey I'm almost 67 years old.

Reviews.Title: Simply Awesome!
Reviews.Author: George
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!!! Takes great shots and easy to operate. I was stuck on my Canon AE-1 because i thought this would be a lot more complicated, this is the beat purchase i have made in a long time. The extended battery pack is a must. I have taken over 1000 since purchasing and i haven't even put a dent on the battery. And that's with playing around with the filters and settings on the camera itself! Just a bit heavy with it but really not bad.

Reviews.Title: Sold my 60 D and bought this instead
Reviews.Author: Anita Howard "Retired and Reading More"
Reviews.Content: I tried this camera out when my daughter in law got it. It was so much lighter than my 60 D. I sold my 60d and got this instead. I love it! Couldn't be happier!

Reviews.Title: Very satisfied with this camera.
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: I am not a professional photographer just a hobbyist and this will not be a real technical review.This camera was bought as an upgrade from my Rebel T3.Needed only the camera body, already have 3 lenses.I do a lot of Macro shots, and when shooting close to the ground with a tripod the Touch Screen is very helpful.Images are nice and sharp using this camera and a 90mm macro lens. And the sharpness really helps when editing them for selective color.All in all I really like this camera. It has enough features to me busy experimenting for a long time.As much as I like my Rebel T3 I think this is a perfect next step.

Reviews.Title: Loving it! Works great for video. Awesome pictures too!
Reviews.Author: Graydon Blair
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a replacement for my Canon XSi (I wanted video in a DSLR) and for my Canon HV30 HD Camcorder.I bought it specifically for the ability to shoot video as well as take pictures at the same time because I was getting tired of lugging BOTH camera's with me to photo shoots.I've now show well over 10 hours of video on it and it worked really well.Video Quality:=============The video quality is really sharp. Colors are nice and it picked them up well. I was shooting in a big warehouse with yellow-ish fluorescent lights above me and some 5200k CFL's pointed right at me. I had to compensate for the yellowing that the florescent above me gave off by switching the white balance mode, but other than that it worked great (not the camera's fault, just really nasty yellow light--that it accurately picked up.I'd say it's definitely better than my old Canon HV30 as far as video quality goes. Not sure about the low light comparison yet--haven't had the need. But with (2) 5200K 65 watt equivalent CFL's pointed at me it was plenty of light and the video came out nice & crisp & bright.Video Editing:=================I edit the video's on an iMac with iMovie and they're really simple to edit.I shot the video's in full HD format and it imports them right in, not a single problem at all.I LOVE being able to pull them right off of the SD card instead of having to suck the video off of a Mini-DV tape with my HV30 hooked up to the computer via Firewire. The camera's worth the money for that alone! Awesome!Some people have complained that the video quality isn't as good in the compression algorithm the camera uses vs Mini-DV HD. To my eyes, the T5i video looks sharper, crisper, and cleaner. And, for my audience, YouTube, it's probably overkill either way, but they still come off great!Yeah, it's an expensive camera if your sole use is YouTube video's, but I have a dual use for it to be able to shoot pictures of the products for my business too, so it was worth it to me. (and it's a heck of a lot less bulk to haul around than a video camera AND a DSLR)Battery Life:============When I first received the camera I ran the included battery out of juice & then let it get a good long charge on it. I then shot a bunch of practice video with it & finally got it to run out of juice after a few hours of use. For my video shoot though I used a Neewer® ACK-E8 AC Power Adapter Supply Kit http://www.amazon.com/Neewer%C2%AE-ACK-E8-Power-Adapter-Supply/dp/B0083EPC80  that I picked up from Amazon that fit perfectly and worked EXTREMELY well, so I'm not really sure how well the batteries will hold up.I did notice that the battery indicator will go from full right to red blinking empty; even with the supplied Canon battery. This only happened on video though. However, if you shut the camera off for 5 minutes, the juice level would come back up a hair. But my Canon Powershot does that too--go figure.Picture Quality============Wow! Wow! And Holy Cow Wow!I really, really like the quality of the 18-135 lens! Definitely an upgrade to the old 18-55 kit lens that came on my XSi. Pictures are much sharper, look brighter, and just look awesome. I also love being able to zoom in.Also, this lens focus's MUCH faster than my old 18-55 kit lens. Like 10x faster! And I love that it's silent.For kicks, I wanted to see how well this thing would shoot a night shot of the stars.I stuck it on a tripod, pointed it in the general direction of the big dipper, eye'd it in through the view finder, put it on P mode and fired it off. It took about 5 seconds to shoot the picture, but wow! An excellent shot! Nice & fairly focused with not a lot of grainyness either. The XSi hasn't ever been able to pull this off. I was really impressed!Ease of Use==============Coming from the XSi, I know my way around the basic setup on the T5i, so I wasn't surprised by anything. I do have to say that I LOVE the touch screen on the back though! Being able to flick through pictures and two finger zoom rocks! Makes checking out what you've shot much, much easier!To me the layout seems the same as the XSi, so I was quickly able to get up & running. The Auto Scene modes seem interesting. Haven't had a lot of time to mess with them much, but they look cool.Bokeh=============I've noticed that this lens will do bokeh (blurred background) shots much easier than my 18-55 lens on the XSi. The pictures come out looking awesome!Audio Quality=============Not the greatest. Ok, let's be honest, it sucks. But I'm used to using a Rode Video Mic, so I slapped that onto the camera, plugged it in & we were back in business. If you're shooting video's for YouTube with this thing (and want any sort of a professional level of audio quality) then get yourself an external mic. You & the people who have to watch your videos will appreciate it much more.I did try an Audio-Technica ATR-3350 Lavalier Omnidirectional Condenser Microphone from Amazon, but it gave off a nasty buzz when plugged into the camera, so I switched back to my tried & true Rode VideoMic & the audio quality came out awesome! (NOTE: If using a video mic, the flash won't pop up all the way...gotta get me a DSLR Rode Mic)Memory============I bought a SanDisk Extreme 32 GB SDHC Class 10 UHS-1 Flash Memory Card 45MB/s and a SanDisk Extreme 16 GB SDHC Class 10 UHS-1 Flash Memory Card 45MB from Amazon when I bought the camera. Both worked exceptionally well with the camera. No complaints at all. I did chew through a full 32 GB and a 16 GB card with all the video I shot, but I offloaded it to an external hard drive & went right back to work.Weight=============With the lens on it, it weighs 2 lbs 8 oz (1128 grams) and it definitely feels heavier than my Canon XSi does, but I think the bulk of that weight is in the lens. Still, it's not too terrible to haul around and it's well balanced.I'm not sure I'd be happy lugging the thing all around say Disneyland or Sea World all day though. I keep mine in a holster type bag with a top handle so that makes it easier to haul around, but hauling 2 lbs with you everywhere of bulk strapped around your neck all day can definitely be a pain. But, the XSi was about the same except a bit lighter.I bought a AmazonBasics Holster Camera Case for DSLR Cameras (Black) with it & didn't care much for it. It had a zippered top instead of a snap which meant I would've had to cram the neck strap into the bag to make it usable. I have an old one (from the XSi) with a front clip that I switched back to because I can use the neck strap on the camera as a holding strap to haul it around in the holster bag with (put the camera in the bag face down, pull the top of the holster bag over the top of the bag, snap it in place with the neck strap hanging out, now I can use the neck strap as the bag strap too--works great this way!)XSi vs T5i comparison==================If you have an older XSi or an XTi and you're wondering if it's worth upgrading....Yes in my case. The picture quality, the quicker focusing, the longer zoom, and the fact that it will AUTO FOCUS the video's that it shoots (and the fact that it actually shoots video at all) won me over--and fast! (anyone looking for an old XSi? LOL!)I'm totally sold on the camera! I've taken it on a few outings with the kids too and it's been a lot of fun to have. I love the 18-135 zoom. For kids soccer games it's just about right. Lets me zoom in but not too far in and it still focuses well.Overall Impression:================The "would I buy it again" question. Yep. Definitely! It was such a marked improvement over the XSi and now that I don't have to lug my Canon HV30 around with me to shoot HD video as well, I'm thrilled! So yes, absolutely, I'd recommend it and would buy another one tomorrow if I needed it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Kenneth A. Klomhaus
Reviews.Content: I will not go into details as so many other reviewers have about this camera.  Let me just say that having owned a Canon T1i, T3i, and now the T5i with the 18-135 STM lens, I cannot be more happy with a camera.  Took it on a trip to Yellowstone this summer and took over a thousand pictures plus an hour or so of video without any problems.  The focus was spot on, the ability to use the touch screen was a great help, and it was a pleasure to use. This week I took it to Starved Rock State Park in Illinois to photograph eagles along the Illinois River.  I was able to capture great photos and video of bald eagles in flight with great color and detail in each photo.  I used a Tamron 18-270 MM VC lens and it worked perfectly with this camera.  I recently added a Tamron 18-200 MM lens to my kit.  It also has worked great with this camera.  I consider myself to be an enthusiast and love digital photography.  I would recommend this camera to anyone who is looking for a DSLR that is much more than an entry level camera.

Reviews.Title: Ridiculously Awesome Camera!
Reviews.Author: Heather Jehnes "Heather"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my husband for Christmas.  He already had a Canon Rebel EOS Xsi SLR camera so I wasn't sure how much better this camera would be but I was shocked.  The pictures he's already taken are amazing and we aren't professionals.  We have a Jack Russell and we are always trying to capture him on camera but most of the shots end up out of focus.  The T5i captures him without any effort and we already have some amazing pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great for pictures, leaves a little to be desired when it comes to video
Reviews.Author: Heather
Reviews.Content: I give this camera five stars for picture quality.  It's amazing.  Coming from a bridge camera this is a huge step up and I'm amazed by the picture quality.  I wanted to learn more about photography but also have something that takes great pictures out of the box.  On auto mode this camera takes wonderful pictures (although I know it pains professionals to hear that anyone uses auto mode).  If you're wanting to move up to a DSLR and are feeling intimidated I can assure you this camera is very user friendly.  After a week shooting in auto I started reading the manual and moving to other modes.  The touch screen is great and the menus are very user-friendly.  When moving to different modes the screen gives a brief description of what that mode does, so for those of us who are learning it's very helpful.  I couldn't be happier with this camera.I went with the 18-135 lens after much debating.  I'm used to a super zoom and was afraid the 18-55 wouldn't be enough for an everyday lens and I wasn't sure I wanted to drag two lenses around with me.  I'm SO happy I went with the 18-135.  It's a great everyday lens, it's not overly bulky and I get plenty of zoom without having to switch lenses.  It's great.The reason for giving this four stars is the video, which I would actually give three stars to.  I went with the T5i because of the STM lens and how great it's supposed to be for video.  I agree that it's totally silent when auto focusing.  I can't hear any noise at all, both when holding my camera and when playing back the video.  The problem is that if you use autofocus in a video it's insanely slow to focus, which basically ruins the video.  It also causes the videos to jump slightly when it comes into focus (still trying to figure out if they all do this or if mine is defective).  I've started taking my videos with manual focus, which is fine, but it defeats the purpose of buying the STM lens.  In hindsight I would have just gotten the T3i since the STM isn't really necessary if I'm manually focusing my videos anyway.  The quality of the video is great as long as the subject isn't moving, but on the best quality setting the files are huge, so keep that in mind when shopping for a memory card.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Digital SLR Camera at a Great Price in this Bundle
Reviews.Author: Jamie Ratliff
Reviews.Content: This is my first Digital SLR camera, and I chose to get the 18-135mm lens with it. I wasn't 100% sure if I wanted a Canon T5i or something else such as a Nikon. I read lots of reviews, but really never found a big difference. I decided on the Canon because a friend of mine has a T3i and loves it. I do plan on shooting some video with it once I get an external microphone, so I was happy to see the video has improved over previous models. It features Full HD Movie mode with Movie Servo AF for continuous focus tracking. The pictures this camera takes are outstanding to say the least, and while I am still learning all the advanced settings, etc, it is easy enough right out of the box for anyone to use in Auto mode. I am very happy with my Canon T5i, and have already purchased a 40mm Canon lens as well as an external flash. I can highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Best purchase this summer
Reviews.Author: Charlie W.
Reviews.Content: I upgraded from a Canon EOS Rebel XTi and I'm so happy I did.  I love this camera and I've been able to ween myself off the basic modes.  I carry it everywhere with me.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful
Reviews.Author: Juan
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because our one of our cameras gave out a couple of days prior to a wedding gig. so I needed a second camera.I was so impressed by the picture quality and the video capabilities, that this is now one of our main cameras when it comes to recording video.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera and Lens
Reviews.Author: Justin Brockman
Reviews.Content: I bought this Camera and Lens and have been absolutely satisfied!  The picture quality is superb and the pixel density is good enough where I can take a wider picture and crop it down considerably and I won't lose any detail!  The touch screen can be difficult to get use to if you are not use to using one but I caught on quickly.  The camera's video function far surpasses any other DSLR I've used so far, the face tracking is stunning!  If you are going to be using a camera for videos, this should be your purchase!  The Kit lens, while isn't bad, is it's weakpoint.  I suggest getting a little more zoom for variability but the lens has nothing wrong with it and produces pictures with great quality!  I recenlty bought a Vivitek 70-200 f2.8 and the image quality got better but the lens is a very good kit lens.

Reviews.Title: Upgraded from a canon T2i very nice Upgrade for me- video review
Reviews.Author: Dave CR "Dave"
